title: RL33929
content: Each year, Congress funds the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to renew over 2.1 million Section 8 vouchers, which are rental subsidies for low-income families in the private market. The vouchers cover the difference between rent and the tenant's expected contribution (30% of adjusted income), with costs varying based on tenant incomes, rents, and payment standards. The cost of a Section 8 voucher to a Public Housing Agency (PHA) is determined by the tenant's actual rent or the maximum subsidy level set by the PHA, and 30% of the tenant's income. Changes in tenant incomes, rents, and payment standards impact this cost. Recent changes in voucher renewal funding distribution have caused funding uncertainty for many PHAs, prompting Congress to consider permanent funding formula changes through Section 8 voucher reform legislation.
